A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Cyclic group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a cyclic group involves the concept of a group being generated by a single element, which means there exists an element in the group such that every other element of the group can be expressed as some power of this generator. This definition inherently relies on the group operation and the properties of groups in general, but it does not specifically require the group operation to be commutative. A cyclic group can be either commutative (abelian) or non-commutative, depending on the nature of the group operation. However, the definition of a cyclic group itself does not necessitate the operation to be commutative; it only requires that all elements of the group can be generated from a single element.\n\nThe Commutative Law, on the other hand, states that a law of composition on a set is commutative if the operation satisfies the condition that the order of operation does not affect the result (i.e., ab = ba for all elements a, b). While many cyclic groups (like those generated by integers under addition) are commutative, the definition of a cyclic group does not inherently require the group's operation to be commutative. Therefore, the concept of the Commutative Law is not necessary for the definition of a cyclic group to make sense.
